awd_titl_txt: Elements: Bringing Montage To Cutting Edge Science Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomy is undergoing a transformation in the way data are acquired, and this is driving a corresponding transformation in the way astronomers process these data.  Telescopes and sky surveys that are operating now or will begin to operate in the coming years will deliver data that are too large and complex to analyze by the traditional method of downloading data to desktops and local clusters.  Thus a transformation is underway to use new technologies to process data. Astronomers have embraced the Python language for analysis because it provides the necessary flexible building blocks to handle complex data, and are embracing new Python-based technologies to manage and control processing that allows the software to run next to the data themselves. The Montage image mosaic engine, a toolkit already used widely by astronomers, will join this transformative community and deliver high-performance, next generation image processing capabilities for astronomers and computer scientists.  It will allow astronomers to create large-scale images of the sky, and study these images with the many powerful tools available in Python.

Python has become the language of choice for astronomy, and environments such as JupyterLabs and JupyterHub are almost certainly the science environments of the future. The LSST is committed to using such an environment for its science platform, which will be the primary way LSST users will discover, access and analyze data. Astronomy science archives are actively building similar platforms. NOAO has deployed their DataLab, which supports datasets acquired at Kitt Peak and CTIO. We will incorporate the functionality of the Montage image mosaic engine - a scalable toolkit written in ANSI-C and in wide use in astronomy and information technology - into environments such as these to unleash its full power when applied to large and complex new datasets. Moreover, the same functionality can be incorporated into a single desktop platform, or into a new scalable environment built to support a new project or mission, or into a distributed scalable environment such the Amazon Elastic Cloud ("bringing the code to the data").  As a component-based toolkit, Montage will be well positioned to respond to the rapid changes expected as these new platforms develop and contribute substantially to understanding their performance and usefulness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Astronomy has entered an era where new missions and telescopes are creating massive and complex  new datasets that will enable exploration of heretofore inaccessible scientific questions. A corresponding transformation in tools for processing, analyzing and visualizing these data is taking place to enable maximum scientific exploitation of them.
The tools themselves are managed and orchestrated by special frameworks, and run atop powerful cyberinfrastructure platforms that run massive programs in parallel. The Montage image mosaic engine has been well suited to participate in this transformation. Its design as a toolkit written in the C programming language (the same language as used for the Linux operating system) ensures that it can run on many platforms.

Visualization of all-sky astronomy images has been transformed by the introduction of Hierarchical Progressive Surveys (HiPS), which permit views of the sky at progressively finer spatial resolution. Montage has been extended to support these HiPS maps. It is unique in in that it can correct maps for the effects of highly variable sky background radiation, and so produces clearer HiPS maps than has hitherto been possible.

Astronomers are developing new platforms for analyzing massive data that move code next to the data. We developed a Jupyter notebook that enables astronomers to create big mosaics via parallel processing on many kinds of higher performance platforms. The notebook uses existing cyberinfrastructure frameworks that manage the processing flow.

The software is freely available, and astronomers have taken advantage of it. A total of 213 astronomy papers have cited Montage during the award period. These papers represent studies carried out across the electromagnetic spectrum, from radio wavelengths to X-rays. They include the highest spatial resolution map of the Galactic center yet acquired at radio wavelengths. A total of 35 projects have incorporated Montage into their environments for processing data and creating products for use by astronomers. Such data have been cited 4,000 times during the period of this award.

Montage runs on many high-performance computers and as such has proven compelling to the computer science community. They have used Montage as a real-world application for developing next-generation computing infrastructure that will be used to support data-intensive processing in the U.S. across many disciplines. This infrastructure includes tools for massive computing on clouds, schedulers for running  complex jobs on high-performance computers, and data orchestration systems that can  recover from processing and hardware failures. The impact is such that over the period of this award, 687 computer science publications cited Montage.

We have been active in the area of education. We have mentored three Summer student interns, part of a program managed by Caltech to engage students from disadvantaged backgrounds in research.  We led a community workshop on the use of managing the economics of commercial cloud platforms, and presented processing of all Transiting Exoplanet Sky Survey (TESS) images with Montage as an exemplar application. The PI gave a Keynote address at the American Astronomical Society meeting in January 2023 entitled "How Can Astronomers Make The Best Use of Cloud Platforms."

We have been collaborating with the United States Geological Survey in their program to predict near real-time predictions of ground motion during earthquakes that will determine who to alert before the wave reaches.  We used Montage to generate contour maps of the expected arrival times of ground motion, and overlaid them on the Google Earth topography.

Montage is recognized as an example of sustainable software, and so the team has, by invitation, been active in national, multi-disciplinary debates on the issues of software transparency and sustainability, and the related issue of verification of published results. These debates, which are taking place across all disciplines, recognize the role played by software in modern research and the need to foster efficiency in software development and transparency in evaluating research claims. The Montage team has helped organize meetings on topics such as Licensing Astrophysics Codes, Best Practices for Software Releases, and Improving Software Citation and Credit, and have made presentations and taken part in panel discussions.
